etymology.description: 金(金) (jīn, "metal") + 羅(罗) (luó, "net") = metal instrument -> gong
etymology.interpretation: The combination of 金(金) (jīn, "metal") as the semantic component indicates that the character relates to metal, while 羅(罗) (luó, "net") provides the phonetic element. The character represents a musical instrument made of metal—specifically a gong.
etymology.simplification: 鑼(鑼) → 锣(鑼): The radical 金(金) (jīn, "metal") is retained while 羅(罗) is simplified to 罗(罗), a common practice in simplification to reduce the stroke count.

examples.chinese: 庙会期间锣声悠扬(廟會期間鑼聲悠揚)。
examples.pinyin: Miào huì qījiān luó shēng yōuyáng.
examples.english: During the temple fair, the sound of the gong resounded melodiously.

examples.chinese: 表演开始时敲响了锣(表演開始時敲響了鑼)，引来了观众(引來了觀眾)。
examples.pinyin: Biǎoyǎn kāishǐ shí qiāo xiǎng le luó, yǐn lái le guānzhòng.
examples.english: When the performance began, the gong was struck, drawing the audience.

examples.chinese: 每当节日来临(每當節日來臨)，村民围坐在锣周围(村民圍坐在鑼周圍)。
examples.pinyin: Měidāng jiérì láilín, cūnmín wéizuò zài luó zhōuwéi.
examples.english: Whenever the festival arrives, the villagers gather around the gong.
